The aims of this article are to: (a) review evidence that social policies may directly alleviate mental_health disparities in LGB populations; (b) examine how these policies may also indirectly lead to positive mental_health outcomes through multiple pathways, including improved access to health-promoting resources, as well as decreases in exposure to stressors and reductions in psychological risk factors for mental_health problems; (c) consider the role that psychologists can play in mitigating mental_health disparities in LGB populations; (d) evaluate the strengths of existing work and propose several areas for future inquiry; and (e) discuss the implications of research for positive social policies enhancing LGB populations.
